title: Piatto ricco...
text: Vulgar Name: Nymph of the arbutus, Jason Family: Nymphalidae Length of front wing mm. 27-33 Note: Caraxes jasius is a nymphalid daytime, beautiful, multi-colored livery and a wingspan that can reach 8 cm .; only representative of a kind Mediterranean widespread in tropical Africa. The habits of Caraxes jasius details. The caterpillar feeds exclusively on the leaves of Arbutus; therefore, its geographical distribution is almost identical to that of the shrub. The caterpillars of Caraxes jasius are solitary, if two individuals meet, they push against the head chief; then everyone goes their own way. Adult males are very pugnacious; when choosing a territory defend doggedly chasing other males and even birds (hoopoe); happened to have given a shot of "wings even in the face of an intruder ... human. Females larger than males, after flying long to reduce the wings to shreds, lay one egg at a time. From the egg comes to light a small caterpillar with red horns, spiny; after being fed on the remains of the egg moves on a leaf which becomes his "home"; only at dusk it has gone away, moving on other leaves on which it feeds; then come back on its "leaf house" following the trail of drool invisible sericea who left leg. After 40 days, the caterpillar, attached to the underside of a leaf, suspended in the air, upside down, it turns into a chrysalis, from which, after 4 weeks flickers adult. Unlike other Lepidoptera, the adults do not like the nectar of the flowers; prefer the ripe fruit sugars, fermentation, from which draw the pulp through the organ mug sucking proboscis said. Male: Dark brown in color. Front wings with the concave edge, a broad band submarginal orange crossed by the ribs black and a series of spaces submarginal gradient of the same color. Rear with serrated edge black, two-tailed black at the third rib median cubital and second, a large orange tinged with yellow marginal band traversed by the black veins and preceded by some blue spaces. Female: Similar to male but larger. Reverse: basal area and discal reddish-brown with patches of greenish gray surrounded by biancocce determine a complex cross-sectional design. Postdiscale white band. In front wings, ribs and marginal premarginale orange. In the hind wings, wing marginal spaces preceded by blue outlined in black. Caterpillar: with small red horns, spiny Distribution: coastal areas of the peninsula and the islands Habitat: Species xerothermophile, frequents the glades of the Mediterranean scrub from sea level up to about 800 meters above sea level Generations per year: Two, with flickering of adults in June and August to September. Plants suckler: Arbutus unedo
